data.text: Numbness on the Buttocks when Cycling Long Distance

What saddles have you used that eliminate or reduce numbness of the nether regions? I'm finding that I'm getting a lot of discomfort with my current saddle which is a WTB something or another...but no grove or cutout. It is the proper width. Might be a Rocket...I'd have to check. But doesn't really matter too much...it needs to be replaced.
Power saddle all the way. Have it on all 7 bikes
data.author: Robert Gawthrop

data.text: Specialized?
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: Yep
data.author: Robert Gawthrop

data.text: I'll check it out. One of the best saddles I ever owned was a Specialized Avatar Gel. But it finally broke and they don't make it anymore.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: I went a few years looking for the right saddle. Once I found the power saddle I never changed again. I really like the short nose as well when I'm standing. I've noticed that you have to dial it in just right though. Especially the nose up/down part. The most miniscule adjustments make a huge difference.
data.author: Robert Gawthrop

data.text: yes, this. I‚Äôve found a 2 degree nose down I was the sweet spot.
data.author: Bill Gaskill

data.text: Brooks c17
data.author: Vecchio Torchio

data.text: I have been very tempted to try a Brooks. I know they do require a break-in period but I hear over and over once they are...there's almost nothing else more comfortable.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: two or three times. After that, they are very very confortable.
data.author: Vecchio Torchio

data.text: I like SQLabs, as does my wife.
data.author: Chris Halle

data.text: Saddles are very personal. What works one doesn't necessarily work for others. My suggestion is to go to a bikefitter or a shop that lets you borrow and try different models until you find one that fits you perfectly.
data.author: Kristjan Kalda

data.text: I don't have that option. That's why I'm looking for suggestions that have worked for others so I can do my own research on those models.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: chromag
data.author: Martin Schoenherr

data.text: Asking for saddle recommendations is like asking for spouse recommendations. While the right one is out there, it‚Äôs different for everyone and the wrong choice will make life hell. Get a bike fit before you spend a dime chasing part swaps in search of comfort.
data.author: Scott Harris

data.text: Been there...done that...still have issues.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: bike fits are a scam. Try different saddles and buy if you like one. If you don't, keep it movin
data.author: Marco Crown

data.text: saddles cost $100 - $400. How many saddles should one try before allowing a ‚Äúscam‚Äù to set them up properly for $200 - $300? Asking for a friend.
data.author: Scott Harris

data.text: I'd rather have a nice collection of bike parts than to hand some guru my cash üòÉ
data.author: Marco Crown

data.text: agree! I have used a certified fitter with great results. Plus the right seat also depends on type of riding... competitive vs leisure vs bike packing will each point to different set ups. A good fitter will help with those decisions.
data.author: Karen Williams

data.text: Bike fits are not available to everyone.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: while I‚Äôm all for a bike fitting, I believe there are good or great saddles under $100.
data.author: Raphael K Koikoi

data.text: absolutely. That wasn‚Äôt really my point. The point is, you could buy (10) $100 saddles throwing darts trying to find comfort and avoid a $300 fitting and one saddle purchase. That‚Äôs not cost effective and is probably making your cycling experience far less enjoyable than it could be. Could you luck out and find the ‚Äúright‚Äù saddle out of the gates? Sure, but it‚Äôd be pure luck if you did and doesn‚Äôt necessarily address other underlying fit issues that are causing your saddle pain.
data.author: Scott Harris

data.text: doesn't sound like the fitter did their job well, my certified fitter identified that my long time favorite Concor Lite 128mm saddle was way too narrow for my measurements. I moved to a 154 Phenom and did away with all of the saddle based issues I'd been having once my butt got used to actually sitting on the saddle. My fitter does lifetime refits on the bike I was fitted for though so if I have any issues I can go back for adjustments until the issue is resolved.
data.author: Mike Johnson

data.text: I like the selle iltalia that came on my grizl and it's made out of something that sticks to my bib shorts which helps staying in place most of the ride. Try it at a shop. I've had a handful of saddles over the years and they all become less comfy the longer your ride is lol
data.author: Marco Crown

data.text: First of all, I‚Äôm a fan of pro bike fits. You‚Äôve already determined width, so that would be second point. I use a Specialized power on road bike(no numbness , but discomfort after 5 hours), and Brooks Cambium on gravel bikes(I never even notice saddle, even after 10+ hours). BUT, I had to tip the nose down on all of them to alleviate numbness. Not more than 10mm though I‚Äôve not measured. It‚Äôs harder to ride with no hands, but worth considering.
data.author: Jake Willits

data.text: does yours squeak? Both my cambiums make a noise. Very comfortable though.
data.author: Tara J C-r

data.text: probably a bit. But I don‚Äôt hear anything less than a bottom bracket anyway.
data.author: Jake Willits

data.text: Vincent Wheels I‚Äôm very happy that you don‚Äôt need a pro fit. I don‚Äôt anymore either(though it was life changing years ago). But in the case of this OP, with numbness in nether region, it‚Äôs definitely not a ‚Äúbullshit‚Äù suggestion.
data.author: Jake Willits

data.text: depends on your anatomy, its an individual thing, my saddles probably wont be good for you
data.author: Nick Roozenburg

data.text: Bike fitting home set by SQLab. Followed instructions, chose SQLab saddle. Tried it, didn't work, returned it and chose another type. And been using them on all bikes ever since.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: Unless you're gonna ride your bike using someone else's ass, what saddle works for other people isn't relevant to your problem. Get a proper fit and have your sit bones and flexibility measured by a professional bike fitter.
data.author: Troy Browning

data.text: but getting some recommendations from others to research further is relevant. A pro bike fitter can't tell me which saddle will work for me any better than anyone here unless the fitter's ass is the one riding my bike...right?
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: no, those recommendations are meaningless. A fitter can absolutely tell you what saddles will work because he's not talking to you about his personal preference or experience, he's talking to you about your biomechanics and your specific measurements. He'll measure YOUR sit bones, he'll test YOUR flexibility, and he'll evaluate YOUR riding position and then find a range of saddle shapes and sizes that work for those specific measurements.
data.author: Troy Browning

data.text: many fitter now use pressure maps to help find you the right saddle. Yes, by measuring your body mechanics and using pressure maps, they absolutely can recommend you the best saddle choices for you.
data.author: Scott Harris

data.text: Brooks Cambium C13 on all my bikes
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: Smp plus
data.author: Jock DeBoer

data.text: Brooks C17 does it for me. But everyone is shaped different

data.text: SMP VT 30c. Super comfortable for long rides.

data.text: After each ride I sit down in a washing up bowl full of custard for an hour whilst reading a book. It doesn't help at all, but it's nice to have a hobby.

data.text: The stock Fizik Argo Terra on my Grizl is an amazing saddle. It has a center cut out as well as a blocking drain pan. It‚Äôs a very comfortable saddle.
data.author: Bryce Petersen

data.text: Brooks c17 cambium with the cutout. Most comfortable saddle ever. Plenty of flexibility and support in the right places.
data.author: Ryan Phillis

data.text: If you‚Äôre in the US, Amazon is a great tool for trying saddles. I purchased 4 different saddles on Amazon and just returned them if I didn‚Äôt like them. Plus they give you like 30 days to return so you can get plenty of miles in for testing üí™üèΩ

data.text: and the ones you return probably get crushed - awesome

data.text: Liked it so much I bought a second one for my Blackborow.

data.text: Very nice! I have the cambium.
data.author: Tara J C-r

data.text: I have two of the same also. One on the errand runner old adventure bike and one on this one.
data.author: Tara J C-r

data.text: In my experience, its not the saddle as much as it is how I sit on the saddle. For whatever reason a lot of riders move forward onto the tounge, so their weight bearing is shifted from the sit bones onto the more sensitive regions. When so, the saddle effectively becomes very narrow. A pro bike fit helps, as well as being conscious of one's sit bone utilization
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: In my experience, lowering your saddle height can fix a lot of pain and numbness issues, regardless of the saddle you have. Give it a try before you drive yourself nuts finding a comfy one. Also Brooks C17 for the win(for my booty anyways)
data.author: John Records

data.text: SQLabs got a 611 on the gravel and 60x on the MTB. Seat shape is personal though, some trial and error at first to find what works. See if a local bike shop has demo seats, that‚Äôs a good way to find one that works.
data.author: Aaron Beckstead

data.text: WTB was my go to, until my short rides were 30 miles. This is my old review , but it still stands Specialized S-Works 3D printed saddle review *** IMPORTANT ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ADDED LATE *** I forgot to mention the saddle rails are oval 7mm x 9mm. Depending on your seatpost clamp mechanism this saddle may or may not properly mount to your seatpost. Here is an account of my experience. First impression... Yeah, it looks bad ass for sure! And it better be all that and more at $450. I weighed it and it‚Äôs definitely light at 193g. Most high line saddles are in the mid 200g range with the lightest saddles weighing in at about half the weight, but that‚Äôs a straight carbon saddle with little or no padding. When I push in the padding in the sit bone area with my thumb to gauge the cushion it pushes in deeply with little resistance, and it‚Äôs firmer in the surrounding areas. I thought it was going to ride like a marshmallow... NOT. When I first sit on it, contrary to what I would expect, it feels quite firm, hard in fact, and for me personally it feels quite ‚Äúflat‚Äù. I think that‚Äôs because rather than higher pressure points under my sit bones with lower pressure on the surrounding areas, my sit bones sink into the seat instantly and spread out the pressure more equally to the surrounding areas. Once I started riding the flat sensation quickly disappeared. It feels very firm, but without pressure points. The further I am into a ride the less I think about the seat. It just disappears from my consciousness. The opposite of all previous saddles where the longer I was into the ride, the more I‚Äôm thinking about the seat and the discomfort. Previously after 35, 50, 70+ miles my sit bone area would become tender and something I had to ‚Äúget through‚Äù until I completed my ride. So far My longest ride has been about 65 miles with NO discomfort what so ever. So back to the price. Yes, it‚Äôs a lot of money for a saddle, too much in fact, but what‚Äôs it worth to you to completely get rid of long ride discomfort? They retail for $450, but you can get one for $385 if you buy directly from Specialized as a ‚Äú1st order‚Äù after opening an account with them. The most I‚Äôve ever paid for a saddle. That said I have more than that amount of money in saddles that are sitting on the shelf in my garage that I‚Äôm not using üòâ I rate it üêçüêçüêçüêçüêç
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: Ok...i get it. Bike saddles are personal. I get that. I know that. I've known that. I've had fittings as well with mediocre results. All I'm trying to do here is complied a list of saddles that others have actual experience riding on with good results so that i can further research and look at reviews and possibly order if I can find vendors that have reasonable return policies. I appreciate all the responses with recommendations.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: I have a Brooks Cambium C15 cutout on my road bike and love it. However, I have WTB Rockets on my Mountain bike and Gravel bike and love them too...so our preferences may differ. Even with a seat I love, I've found the chamois in the kit makes a big difference between not noticing the seat at all and shifting around a little. I've had great results from Pearl Izumi's higher end (Elite and up). Garneau is hit or miss for me.
data.author: Jamie Cornett

data.text: S-Works Power with mirror. You‚Äôre welcome.
data.author: Bill Gaskill

data.text: Selle Anatomica X - you don't even need a chamois after a couple of weeks (assuming you're not a regular rider - if so you probably wouldn't need them from day 1)..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: 155mm specialized power arc pro, or whatever it is called. Unfortunately that bike was stolen and I‚Äôve never been able to justify dropping that kind of cash on a saddle since. Now, I just get the EC90 fake version for like $25 and it works pretty damn well
data.author: Jim Ryan

data.text: Ride more hills to keep you out of the seat.
data.author: Mark Frazier

data.text: brooks flyer. Came on a bike I bought. Comfort and looks!
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: Fabric Scoop Radius saddle. Fits me perfect and it‚Äôs affordable. Nothing super light weight or fancy name.
